feed.title: Haohu Shen's ePortfolio
feed.subtitle: Programming is the art of telling another human being what one wants the computer to do.

entry.content:
The Disjoint Set Union and its Optimizations in the Coding Competition

Contents

0x00 Preface
0x01 The Normal Disjoint Set
0x02 The Disjoint Set with Path Compression Optimized
0x03 The Disjoint Set with Rank By Size Optimized
0x04 The Complexity of Operations on the Disjoint Set
0x05 References and Exercises

0x00 Preface

The Disjoint Set, or Union Find, or DSU, is a data structure that provides some functions, suppose we are given several elements where each is a separate set, and we are also given some instructions to combine random sets, and the disjoint set can tell us if any of two elements are in the same set at any time. The data structure is pretty common in coding competitions, especially in graph problems. In this article, I will give a short introduction to the interface of a Disjoint Set, and then two optimizations on it.

0x01 The Normal Disjoint Set

Any disjoint set should support three basic operations:

  • Initialization: Given elements, each element should be initialized as an isolated set.

  • Find: Given an element, return the set it belongs to

  • Merge: Given two element and , merge the set where is and the set where is as one.

So you can see that DSU does not support the operation that splits two sets, but a modified DSU is able to support the deletion of a single element in a set, see Kattis Almost Union-Find.

Thus, we can have the code for the initialization:

Apparently, the recursion will be eventually terminated if the ancestor is found.

0x02 The Disjoint Set with Path Compression Optimized

But it is inefficient to find the ancestor by asking fathers one by one, since who is my ancestor has nothing to do with who is my father, we can make the family member the son of the ancestor. It is not important who is the ancestor, as long as there is someone who can represent the whole family, thus, we can directly connect the node to the root of the tree, as below:

The code is also easily implemented:

Thus the code can be easily implemented as below:

In the party, an ancestor of a family wants to merge with another family since both families are in a good relationship. Just like I said before, we do not care who is the ancestor as long as there is someone who can represent the whole family. Thus we let one ancestor be the son of another ancestor. That is how two sets are merged in DSU, as below:

The code is also easily implemented:

0x03 The Disjoint Set with Rank By Size Optimized

When we merge two sets in DSU, no matter which set is being merged into, the result is the same. But if we choose a different set to be merged into, the time complexity may be different. More specifically, if we merge a tree which represents a set in DSU with a smaller size or smaller depth into another tree with a bigger size or bigger depth, it is better than vice versa. Thus we can have another array to store the size of each set, and every time we merge two sets, we will choose the smaller set to be the one that is being merged into. And this is the optimization by size.

Here is the implementation:

0x04 The Complexity of Operations on the Disjoint Set

After applying the optimization of path compression and rank by size, the amortized time complexity of each operation in DSU is only where is the inverse Ackermann function, which is less than 5 for any practical input size .

For space complexity, since we only use two arrays to store information, we can easily know it is where is the number of elements in the DSU.

Finally, we can wrap all functions mentioned above into a namespace:

0x05 References and Exercises

Ackermann function

Disjoint Set Union

Association for Control Over Minds

Tildes

Union-Find

Virtual Friends

The Application of Policy-Based Data Structure in GCC for Coding Competition

0x00 Preface

If you ask a C++ coding competitor why he or she chooses such language, he or she may tell you one reason is that C++ STL is powerful since it has already provided a lot of data structures, such as priority queue, and hashmap. It also provides some built-in algorithms, covering sorting, merging, and high-order functions. However, STL still does not provide some other data structures, such as trie for coding competitors. Luckily we have a GCC extension called Policy Based Data Structure (PBDS) that covers some advanced data structures, such as a red-black tree that has order statistics, a trie or a pairing heap. If we are allowed to use them in the competition, it will hugely save you time and you donâ€™t need to implement them again and again.

Unlike my other articles, this article is a short introduction to some basic usage of this extension. And before that, you need to include its relative header files like this:

Alternatively, there is another way to make it shorter, like this:

Contents

0x00 Preface
0x01 Hashmap or hashset using PBDS
0x02 Red black tree of PBDS
0x03 Trie of PBDS
0x04 Priority Queue of PBDS
0x05 Reference and Exercises

0x01 Hashmap or hashset using PBDS

There are two types of hash maps in PBDS, we can define them like this:

Unlike std::unordered_map, cc_hash_table are collision-chaining hash-based, while gp_hash_table are probing hash-based.

If you want to make them into hash sets, we can define their values like this:

And its usage is pretty similar to std::unordered_map, here is an example:

Similar to std::unordered_map, you can also provide a custom hash function to it:

So how is its performance, well, I did a benchmark on these 3 types of hashmaps by insertion and deletion of numbers from 0 to 1000000 multiple times to compare their average time cost and here is the result:

So normally if gp_hash_table is allowed in the competition, it would be your first choice, a better hash function will further help increase the performance.

0x02 Red black tree of PBDS

Since the data structure under std::map is a red-black tree, it has no public API and it does not provide a rank-query interface. Luckily, PBDS provides three types of balanced trees, that is red-black tree, splay tree and ov-tree. I will focus on the red-black tree since it is faster in most cases than the other two, here is an example, and remember, keys in a red-black tree are unique:

And remember that all operations above except for the size checking is where is the number of nodes in the tree.

0x03 Trie of PBDS

The way to define and use a trie is pretty similar to the red-black tree, here is an example:

0x04 Priority Queue of PBDS

There are multiple implementations of priority queue in PBDS, all of them can be defined as below, with integers as keys:

The tag can be pairing_heap_tag, thin_heap_tag, binomial_heap_tag, rc_binomial_heap_tag, binary_heap_tag, here is the complexities of the different underlying data structures in terms of orders of growth, which comes from the GNU officialâ€™s documentation:

Thus, in most cases, you should choose the pairing heap as the first option, since it is faster than the other five types of heaps. At the end of the article, I will share with you the implementation of Dijkstraâ€™s algorithm for searching the shortest path from a to b using a pairing heap, which is a template I use often in the coding competitions:

0x05 Reference and Exercises

C++ STL: Policy-based data structures

Performance of PBDS

Kattis: Baby Names

Kattis: Continuous Median

Kattis: Galactic Collegiate Programming Contest

Coding Template

This is the full version of my personal coding template for competitive coding in C++, suppose we are using GCC with standard C++17.

entry.content:
Notes - Highlight some key features/common traps in programming

Welcome to this section of my blog, a collection of code snippets for programming novices. In this fast-paced tech world, I believe learning should be straightforward and direct. This tag is specifically crafted for beginners, encompassing everything from Java to Golang, algorithms to data structures, and Docker to Linux basics. Each note is a carefully selected quick tip, designed to help you swiftly grasp key concepts and skills.

Notice some notes may contain Chinese since I am a Chinese/English bilingual.

  • C++

  • Redis/MongoDB/MinIO

  • Mybatis Plus

  • Docker

  • C++ Template for Competitive Programming

My Projects

Welcome to my Projects space, where I showcase a collection of SOLO projects Iâ€™ve independently developed since I was an undergrad. Each project here is a testament to my personal technical skills and innovative thinking. From conception to execution, every piece encapsulates my passion and dedication. In these records, youâ€™ll not only see the final outcomes but also gain insights into the development process, challenges faced, and how I turned ideas into reality.

K-Way Merger

This project is a toy implementation of a K-way Merger in Go, designed with functionality and efficiency in mind. The application operates in a multi-step process:

  • It begins by accepting a list of input files along with a specified output file.

  • The core functionality involves sorting integers in each input file in ascending order, with the sorted data then being rewritten back to the respective input files.

  • Finally, the application seamlessly merges all integers from these input files. This merging process is efficiently handled using a binary heap algorithm, culminating in the combined result being written to the designated output file.

This implementation not only demonstrates the practical application of sorting and merging algorithms but also showcases the power and flexibility of Go in handling data-intensive tasks.

Atomic Heart Dot Lock Cracker

Iâ€™ve developed a Command Line application in C++ designed to assist players in swiftly unlocking dot locks in the game Atomic Heart. Users input two arrays reflecting the lockâ€™s initial and target patterns. The app then calculates and outputs the most efficient sequence for unlocking, guiding users through the precise key presses on the PS5 controller. With small modifications, the user can make it support the game on different platforms.

A Toy Implementation of Different Caches in C++

This project presents the implementation of four cache replacement policies, each meticulously crafted using single-threaded programming in C++. The policies include:

  • First-In-Last-Out (FILO): A unique approach where the most recently added items are the first to be evicted.

  • First-In-First-Out (FIFO): A classic strategy that removes items in the order they were added, ensuring a fair and sequential process.

  • Least Recently Used (LRU): This policy prioritizes user recency, discarding items that havenâ€™t been accessed for the longest time.

  • Least Frequently Used (LFU): Focusing on usage frequency, this method eliminates items with the least number of accesses.

Each policy is meticulously coded in C++, demonstrating not only the power of the language in handling complex algorithms but also providing a practical viewpoint into the efficiency and applicability of these policies in real-world scenarios.

A Toy Implementation of Arbitrary-Precision Fraction in Java

The project includes the implementation of a Java Arbitrary-precision fraction, utilizing the class BigIntegers for numerator and denominator. Fraction is always kept in the lowest terms. Fraction is immutable and guaranteed not to have a null numerator or denominator. The denominator will always be positive (thus sign is carried by the numerator), and the denominator is not allowed to be zero.
entry.summary:
My Projects

Welcome to my Projects

entry.content:
About Me

I am a passionate enthusiast in backend, cloud-native, and distributed development. My journey in computer science began at the University of Calgary, where I completed my undergraduate studies. After a brief stint in C++ development, I am currently pursuing a Master of Engineering degree in Telecommunications & Information Security at the University of Victoria, with a focus on Linux operations and security.

My keen interest in algorithms and data structures was highlighted when I secured a silver medal at the 2021 ICPC North American Rocky Mountain Regional. I am deeply fascinated by Unixâ€™s design philosophy and have a profound understanding of software design patterns and architecture. I enjoy delving into the intricacies of code while maintaining a grasp of the broader aspects of software architecture.

Through this blog, I aim to document my learning journey and those easily forgettable yet crucial knowledge points. I believe in growing and exploring the ever-evolving world of technology through sharing and collaboration.

Reference:

  • My Resume
  • Certificate of ICPC Silver Medal

About Me

entry.content:
Benchmark the Fastest Way of I/O in C++ for Coding Competition

Contents

0x00 Preface
0x01 How to set the benchmark of different ways of I/O?
0x02 How to wrap the faster way of I/O?
0x03 How to tweak the faster way of I/O to handle different variadic arguments?
0x04 What you should know if you want to use the wrapper in a real competition?
0x05 Reference

0x00 Preface

When a coding competitor encounters a problem that requires a large size of input/output and limited time, I/O will become the bottleneck of the solution. Especially C++ programmers will find that cin/cout will always be slower than scanf/printf, thus in this article, I will share with you guys how I find the fastest way to read from standard input and write to standard output in C++ by setting up a benchmark and how I wrap the facility in a coding competition. Finally, I will share with you some tips you should notice if you really want to use the code for fast input/output, and a disadvantage of it.

On the other hand, since in most competitions, problem graders are running on a Linux machine and the source code of C++ will be compiled in GCC, I decided to use the following environment to benchmark the code for faster I/O:

  • Fedora in csx.cs.ucalgary.ca by Secured Shell
  • Compile in g++ with -O2 using C++17 standard

In this way, you can also verify or re-benchmark by yourself.

0x01 How to set the benchmark of different ways of I/O?

In most cases, if a problem requires large size of input/output and limited time in the coding competitions, we can assume that the data type for input/output is integers, therefore, in order to benchmark, we need a generator that creates specified random integers to a specified external file, as below:

On the other hand, to benchmark different methods, I decide to generate 10000000 integers, start measuring the time before reading from standard input or writing to standard output and stop measuring the time once the job is done, as below:

Right now, I am going to share with you all methods for reading and writing:

  • cin/cout

For most C++ beginners, cin/cout is a nice and convenient way to read from stdin until EOF and write to stdout, as below:

The buffer will be flushed after every endl, thus we can make it quicker by flushing the buffer only once after EOF, like this:

  • cin/cout without synchronization

One reason that cin/cout is slower is that for compatibility cin/cout is designed to sync with printf/scanf at default, thus the order of input/output is clear if you mix using two pairs of different ways to handle I/O. Thus we can cancel such sync and only use cin/cout or printf/scanf in our solution. In this way, the time cost of I/O will be significantly reduced. Meanwhile, we can also cancel the binding between cin and cout. And donâ€™t forget to avoid using endl for flushing the buffer only once, like this:

  • getchar/putchar

If you parse the integer and output the integer by digits using getchar/putchar, it will be faster than any methods above, meanwhile, we can use recursion in putchar, which is a little bit faster than using a stack to store each digit, as below:

If we only need to parse an integer and store it to a reference instead of checking if there is an EOF, we can use the code below, which is actually more common in competitions:

Moreover, since coders are allowed to use only a single thread in the competition, we donâ€™t need to consider situations such as multi-threads, or sharing variables, thus we can replace getchar and putchar with their thread-unsafe versions, getchar_unlocked and putchar_unlocked. Similarly, we can use fputs_unlocked to output C-style strings.

  • fread/fwrite

We can even make it faster by reading all input into a buffer using fread and outputting the whole contents from the buffer once and for all with fwrite, since coders are given the size of data in many coding problems, they are able to estimate the size of buffers used for input/output. We use two pointers to point at these two buffers respectively, when a digit is parsed for input/output, pointers will advance for a step as below, notice donâ€™t forget to flush the buffer:

  • More faster method of I/O?

Is there an even faster method for input/output in C++? Well, instead of writing into a buffer, we can always map stdin into memory directly, it will be a little faster than fread. The function mmap helps us do the job easily, but it also requires us to include additional header files, if you really want to use it, make sure it is legal in the competition. Here I wrap a thread-unsafe mmap/fwrite into a namespace:

  • BENCHMARK

    So what is the benchmark of different methods after all these tests? Well, here are two tables of results, I tested reading and writing 10000000 integers separately on the server of UofC by SSH:

    For input, we have:

    METHODTIME COST (seconds)
    mmap0.333833
    fread0.493002
    getchar unlocked0.433707
    getchar0.619069
    scanf1.62939
    cin without sync1.7917
    cin5.04564

    Also, for output, we have:

    METHODTIME COST (seconds)
    fwrite0.735085
    putchar unlocked0.826488
    putchar0.815868
    printf1.41162
    cout without sync1.36623
    cout30.6118

    Now you see that different ways of I/O may make a huge impact on the time cost of a routine in coding competitions. For unknown reasons, putchar unlocked is a little bit slower than putchar, but it will definitely be faster than printf.

0x02 How to wrap the faster way of I/O?

Since mmap is only available in Linux machines and there are some problems out there that you cannot predict the size of input/output, I decided to take getchar/putchar methods and wrap it into a namespace, which has better readability. Now since we may read integers that have a wider range in real problems, so I also decided to wrap it with C++ templates, thus the user can also process data types such as long long with it, with the help of template argument deduction in C++17, you donâ€™t need to explicitly indicate the type.

0x03 How to tweak the faster way of I/O to handle different variadic arguments?

Since C++11 we have Parameter pack that accepts zero or more template arguments, we can simply pack variadic arguments and process them using recursion, and now we can have the full demo code with the final version of a wrapper:

You can try this problem with and without using the fast IO method, and here are my two different time costs. You can see in this case the fast IO method hugely helps you reduce the run-time, even though the algorithm is the same.

0x04 What you should know if you want to use the wrapper in a real competition?

Well, for problems that only require you to read or write wrappers, you could just use it in the competition. On the other hand, if the problem requires you to process strings, you should use scanf or cin without sync and std::string. If you have to handle numbers and strings at the same, donâ€™t use the wrapper and cin/cout without syncing together since the sync between cin/cout and getchar/putchar is cancelled.

0x05 References

Implementation of fast IO in C++

Shellscript to run the benchmark

Solution of Problem 6365 in Luogu

Problem Link (in Chinese):

Frequency of the Mode

Problem Description

In the classroom of Intelligence Specialized Training students, to liven up the atmosphere and reinforce the knowledge of bitwise operations, the students started playing a game.

There are students in the class, and each student has two cards, a red card or a black card. Each card has a non-negative integer that does not exceed . The red card number of the -th student is , and the black card number is .

Now, each student needs to play a card. Each student can either directly play the number on their red card or play the result of the bitwise XOR operation between their red and black card numbers. Finally, the teacher will collect all the numbers played by the students.

The number that appears the most among these numbers is the mode. With the best cooperative strategy for all students, we hope that the frequency of the mode is as high as possible. What is the number that appears the most?

Input

The first line contains a positive integer .

The following lines, where the -th line contains non-negative integers , representing the numbers on the red and black cards of the -th student.

Output

An integer, representing the answer. If there are multiple solutions, please output the smallest one.

Sample #1

Sample Input #1
Sample Output #1

Explanation

The mode can appear at most times, and there are two ways to achieve this:

  • The 1st student plays the red card directly, the 2nd student plays the XOR of red and black, the 3rd student plays any card, and the 4th student plays the XOR of red and black. In this way, students 1, 2, and 4 can all play .
  • The 1st student plays the XOR of red and black, the 2nd student plays the red card directly, the 3rd student plays the red card directly, and the 4th student plays any card. In this way, students 1, 2, and 3 can all play .

Therefore, both and are the modes that appear the most, as they can appear up to times, and there is no scheme where they appear times. However, since the smaller one should be output if there are multiple solutions, please output .

Solution

  • Problem Analysis

    To find the mode, we first need to count all possible card-playing scenarios for each student and calculate the frequency of each scenario. The smallest value among those with the highest frequency is what we are looking for. Since each student may play a red card or the XOR of two cards, we can handle this in two sub-cases:

    • If the red card played by the student and the XOR of two cards are different, they need to be counted separately.

    • If the red card played by the student and the XOR of two cards are the same, it is counted only once.

    Therefore:

    • To achieve fast access and update of frequencies during counting, a hash table is used for storage.
      The implementation of the hash table can use std::unordered_map or __gnu_pbds::gp_hash_table, with the latter being used here.

    • To prevent the XOR value from exceeding the int range, long long is used.

    • To reduce the basic operation time complexity of the hash table to
      O(n) in the case of special inputs, Codeforcesâ€™ anti-hack hash function is used, referenced from https://codeforces.com/blog/entry/62393.

    • To find the smallest value among those with the highest frequency, a linear check is needed after calculating the maximum frequency.

    • To avoid potential constant optimization issues, fast input and output can be added.

  • The code below is compiled using the C++17 standard and O2 optimization.

entry.content:
My Blogs

Welcome to my Blog Section!

This blog is a collection of some of my coding experience and skills used in coding competitions as well as solutions for some coding problems that I found interesting.

One thing you will notice is that almost all the code for solving problems in competitive programming is written in C++, why? Well, here are some reasons:

  • C++ is faster and easier to tweak than other languages in real coding competitions.

  • C++ has STL, which implements a lot of built-in data structures and algorithms and thus brings much convenience to coders.

  • You can directly use CPU instructions or inline assembly code in C++ for optimization, even though such case is pretty rare.

There are other advantages of using C++ in coding competitions since it can help you get in touch with the hardware more easily than other languages.

Anyway, unlike those WIKI algorithms, this blog just contains some techniques or introductions of some data structures I found useful and not that hard to understand for a CS student. Happy reading!

  • Benchmark the Fastest Way of I/O in C++ for Coding Competition

  • The Application of Policy Based Data Structure in GCC for Coding Competition

  • The Tricks of Modulo Operation with Exponentiation for Coding Competition

  • The Disjoint Set Union and its Optimizations in the Coding Competition

  • Solution of Problem 6581 in Luogu

  • Solution of Problem 5238 in Luogu

  • Solution of Problem 1226 in Luogu

  • Solution of Problem 6365 in Luogu

entry.content:
Solution of Problem 6581 in Luogu

Problem Link (in Chinese):

P6581

Problem Description

You are given an integer ï¼Œobtain the number of possible s such that .

Input

an integer

Output

an integer indicates the number of possible s

Sample #1

Sample Input #1
Sample Output #1

Sample #2

Sample Input #2
Sample Output #2

Sample #3

Sample Input #3
Sample Output #3

Explanation for sample #1

could be -1, 0, 1.

Input Size

indicates the absolute value of .

Solution

The key to this problem is to solve the absolute value inequality and the handling of integer range overflow:

  • Based on the problem description, we need to determine the number of possible values for given . Therefore, we can discuss it based on the range of :

    • If , then , which implies . However, by the definition of absolute value, we know , so there are no solutions in this case.

    • If , then we have , and thus the number of possible values for that satisfy this inequality is .

  • In this problem, the range of is , so there is a potential for overflow beyond the range of a long integer when calculating . However, the result will definitely be within the range of unsigned long long, so we can use __int128 to handle the intermediate process, and then convert the type back to unsigned long long for the result. The sample answer code is shown below:

Code

  • The code is compiled using the C++17 standard with O2 optimization enabled.
